Write me a .clangd file

Certainly! A `.clangd` file is used to configure the behavior of the `clangd` language server. Below is an example of a `.clangd` configuration file:

```yaml
CompileFlags:
  # Add extra flags to the compile command.
  Add: [-Wall, -Wextra, -Werror]

# Paths to search for compile_commands.json.
CompileCommands:
  # If specified, clangd will look for compile_commands.json in these directories.
  # If not specified, clangd will look in the current directory and parent directories.
  Paths: [build, .]

# Indexing options
Index:
  # Whether to index files in the background and persist index on disk.
  Background: true
  # Whether to include the standard library in the index.
  StandardLibrary: true

# Clang-tidy options
ClangTidy:
  # Enable clang-tidy diagnostics.
  Add: [-checks=*, -warnings-as-errors=*]
  # Path to clang-tidy executable.
  Path: /usr/bin/clang-tidy

# Completion options
Completion:
  # Whether to include snippets in code completion.
  Snippets: true
  # Whether to include code patterns in code completion.
  Patterns: true

# Diagnostics options
Diagnostics:
  # Whether to show diagnostics from clang-tidy.
  ClangTidy: true
  # Whether to show diagnostics from the compiler.
  Compiler: true

# Formatting options
Format:
  # Whether to enable formatting on save.
  OnSave: true
  # Path to clang-format executable.
  Path: /usr/bin/clang-format

# Header Insertion options
HeaderInsertion:
  # Whether to insert #include directives automatically.
  Include: true
  # Whether to insert #include directives for standard library headers.
  StandardLibrary: true

# Memory usage options
MemoryUsage:
  # Maximum memory usage for clangd in MB.
  Limit: 4096

# Miscellaneous options
Misc:
  # Path to the clangd executable.
  Path: /usr/bin/clangd
```

This is a basic configuration file and can be customized further based on your specific needs. Save this content to a file named `.clangd` in the root of your project directory.
